texts.shortText:
Ampeliscidae are a common and diverse family of benthic, tube-dwelling amphipods, fairly easily recognized to group by the fact that most species have two pairs of red eyes, each topped by a round, shiny corneal lens. Their bodies are soft and laterally flattened, the antennae generally long and hairy, the claws weak or absent and the first two pairs of walking legs contain cloud-like spinning glands used to secrete the tubes.

There are more than a dozen hard to identify species in the region and these are separated largely by detailed structures of the last pair of walking legs (see Griffiths, 1976 for guide to species). This species is particularly large and common and is featured here mainly because it can be fairly readily identified by the conspicuous rounded lobe on the posterior of the last walking leg.
Adult up to 12 mm body length (excluding antennae).

Global: Europe, Mediterranean and South Africa (the South African form likely is distinct from that in Europe).

Local/Regional: Whole region.

Like most other ampeliscids found in dense colonies occupying soft sediments to depths of at least 200 m. Occupies delicate vertical tubes spun from sediment particles and extends the setose antennae from the tubes to capture fine organic particles which are sorted by the mouthparts and either ingested or used for tube construction.
When feeding the antennae are projected out of the burrow opening and are used to filter organic particles from the water passing overhead.
Sexes separate. Females brood their eggs in a marsupial chamber between the legs, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles which are then released into the water.

There are over 200 species globally in the genus Ampelisca, of which 14 are found in South Africa. These are mostly difficult to separate, so only this species is featured to represent the normal sediment dwelling forms. The only other species described on this site is the strange A. excavate, which has the unique habitat of taking over the abandoned burrows of dead burrowing barnacles and has a modified body structure to adapt itself to this habitat.
Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum (p. 23).
